ul.li1: 1See, a king will rule according to righteousness,
ul.li2: and princes will rule according to justice.
ul.li1: 2And each one will be like a hiding place from the wind
ul.li2: and a covering from the rainstorm,
ul.li1: like streams of water in a dry region,
ul.li2: like the shade of a large rock in a weary land.
ul.li1: 3And the eyes of those who see will not gaze,The same consonants with different vowels would be translated “be blinded,” which fits the context better
ul.li2: and the ears of those who hear will listen.
ul.li1: 4And the mindsLiterally “heart” of the rash will understand knowledge,Literally “to know”
ul.li2: and the tonguesHebrew “tongue” of stammerers will hasten to speak clearly.
ul.li1: 5A fool will no longer be called noble,
ul.li2: and a scoundrel will not be said to be eminent.
ul.li1: 6For a fool speaks folly,
ul.li2: and his mindLiterally “heart” does iniquity:
ul.li1: to behave wickedly,Literally “do ungodliness”
ul.li2: and to speak error concerning Yahweh,
ul.li1: to leave the throat of the hungry empty,
ul.li2: and he deprives the thirsty of drink.
ul.li1: 7And a scoundrel, his weapons are evil;
ul.li2: he plans evil devices
ul.li1: to ruin the poor with words of deception
ul.li2: evenOr “and” when the speech of the needy is right.
ul.li1: 8ButOr “And” the nobleman plans noble things,
ul.li2: and he stands upon noble things.

ul.li1: 9Women who are at ease, rise up; hear my voice!
ul.li2: Carefree daughters, listen to my word!

chapter.p: 10In a yearLiterally “In days upon a year” you will tremble, carefree ones,

ul.li1: for the vintage will come to an end;
ul.li2: the harvest will not come.
ul.li1: 11Tremble, you who are at ease;
ul.li2: tremble, carefree ones;
ul.li1: strip, and strip yourself,
ul.li2: and gird yourself on your loins,Although the carefree and at ease addressees in this verse are feminine plural (“you women”), the commands are masculine singular in form
ul.li1: 12mourning over breasts,
ul.li2: over fields of delight,
ul.li1: over the fruitful vine,
ul.li2: 13over the soil of my people.
ul.li1: It goes up in thornsHebrew “thorn” and briers,Hebrew “brier”
ul.li2: indeed over all of the houses of joy in the jubilant city.
ul.li1: 14For the palace will be forsaken,
ul.li2: the crowded cityLiterally “crowd of the city” deserted;
ul.li1: the hill and the watchtower will becomeThe Hebrew text has “for the benefit of” following “become” a cave forever,
ul.li2: the joy of wild asses, a pasture forLiterally “of” flocks.

chapter.p: 15Until a spirit is poured out on us from on high,

ul.li1: and the wilderness becomes a fruitful field,
ul.li2: and the fruitful field is reckoned as the forest.
ul.li1: 16ThenOr “And” justice will dwell in the wilderness,
ul.li2: and righteousness will live in the fruitful field.
ul.li1: 17And the work of righteousness will be peace,
ul.li2: and the work of righteousness, quietness and security forever.
ul.li1: 18And my people will dwell in a settlement of peace
ul.li2: and in a dwelling place of security
and in undisturbed resting places.
ul.li1: 19And it hails when the forest comes down,Literally “the coming down of the forest”
ul.li2: and the city will become low in humiliation.
ul.li1: 20Happy are you who sow by all waters,
ul.li2: who let the foot of the ox and the donkey go free.
